Mistletoe -- lots of it, & easy to see here during the sycamores' brief leafless period -- the ranger said the sycamores shed their leaves and grow new ones almost immediately in this hot climate. Pretty sure this is Phoradendron macrophyllum. P. coryae is the only Arizona species that looked similar, but is found mainly on oaks, whereas macrophyllum is found on a variety of non-oak deciduous sp. P. tomentosum is the only species listed on the Montezuma's Castle checklist, but looks like the species has been split -- P. tomentosum sensu stricto is not found in AZ.

And for the record, no nesting birds were harassed to get this photo -- taken at 15x zoom from the walkway far below, along the base of the cliff.

This is a large cenote (limestone sinkhole) with very interesting water chemistry. It's completely unlike anything else around in this area, and holds water year-round, making it an important site in this desert environment. Folks in the boat are biologists working on a project to trap and remove nonnative turtles (sliders -- a population introduced by people dumping unwanted pet turtles here) to protect the native Sonoran Mud Turtles. They're not endangered, but this is the northernmost extent of their range. And more importantly, the ecosystem of the Well is unique and fragile.
boat cenote limestone geology karst sinkhole nationalmonument montezumaswell montezumascastlenationalmonument

Emesis zela. This species is found in the US only in a very restricted band along the Mogollon Rim in Arizona, although it is listed as common in appropriate habitat there -- namely, riparian sycamore woods, which is exactly where I found it. Got a good look thru binocs -- hindwing above bright orange with concentric dark banding, forewing above with dark shading along the central part of the median line. Unfortunately it didn't let me get a shot -- only one I got was a zoom macro with it perched far above our heads in a tree.

I learned this as Western Sycamore, but it looks like the Arizona has been split from the California -- or maybe it's only the Calif. that's called Western. At any rate, looks very similar to the ones I remember from Calif.; and distinctly different from the Eastern species (American Sycamore), which typically grows from a single, straight trunk & has darker, peely bark all the way up, not just around the base.

Scroll down for side view showing leaves & fruit. Flower ~8 mm across. Little weedy thing, only seen in this high-foot-traffic riparian area.

Fascinating textures in the rock here. I think this is typical of karst, & that it is a type of cavernous weathering, but I don't know for sure, and don't know what the mechanism responsible for it is.

George Rothrock was the first photographer to set up shop in Phoenix (which is about a 100-mile drive south of here) and one of the pioneering photographers of the West. <a href"http:vintagephoto.comreferenceRothrockArticle.pdf">vintagephoto.comreferenceRothrockArticle.pdf<a> is an extensive article on him and has one of his photos of Montezuma's Well. (It's a stereo pair, too, although it's intended for a mechanical viewer so it's backwards when viewed cross-eyed).

Lesquerella sp. -- not sure which. Not a great shot, but the flowers down at the bottom are in focus (sorta). Not to be confused (as I did!) with the bush called Bladderpod (Cleome isomeris).
